Topics: Identity of Muhammad ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Abi Layla

hadiths.english_translation: From the group of Banu Juhijah ibn Kulfa from Banu Amr ibn Awf from al-Aws - they unanimously agreed that he died in Kufa in the year 148 AH. He had served as judge for the Umayyads, then he served as judge for the Abbasids during the governorship of Isa ibn Musa over Kufa and its territories. Al-Fadl ibn Dukain reported to us, saying: When Muhammad ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Abi Layla died, he had reached seventy-two years of age.

narrators.name: Al-Fadl ibn Dukain
narrators.full_name: Al-Fadl ibn Dukain ibn Dinar al-Kufi
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Yahya al-Kufi, Fadl ibn Dukain

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Abi Layla
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Abi Layla ibn Bilal ibn Bulayl al-Ansari

chainIssues: Two transmission terms used: أَخْبَرَنَا (strong) and قَالَ (weaker) indicating indirect connection from Ibn Abi Layla
This is primarily biographical/historical information rather than a hadith transmission
The chain terminates at a tabaqah (generation level) rather than connecting to the Prophet ﷺ or a Companion

potential_issues.impact: While Al-Fadl ibn Dukain uses the direct term 'akhbarana', Ibn Abi Layla's report uses 'qala' which is less direct, though not significantly problematic given both narrators' reliability
This entry is primarily historical biographical information (death date and age) rather than a religious hadith or legal ruling

potential_issues.issue: Chain does not connect to Prophet ﷺ or established Companion
potential_issues.impact: The chain is mawquf (stopped), ending at Ibn Abi Layla's biographical account of his ancestor

Topics: Death of Muhammad ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Abi Layla

hadiths.english_translation: Ahmad ibn Abdullah ibn Yunus reported to us, he said: Abu Shihab narrated to us, he said: Ibn Abi Layla reported to us, he said: I do not remember anything from my father's affairs, except that I know he had two wives, and he had two green vessels, he would prepare fermented drink at this one on one day, and at that one on another day.

narrators.full_name: Ahmad ibn Abdullah ibn Yunus al-Amarri al-Kufi

potential_issues.impact: Muhammad ibn al-Sa'ib al-Kalbi is widely known among hadith scholars as a weak narrator prone to fabrication and errors in genealogies and traditions

potential_issues.issue: No transmission chain or hadith content
potential_issues.impact: This entry contains only genealogical information with no actual hadith transmission to analyze or authenticate
Al-Kalbi's genealogies are known to be unreliable, so even the genealogical information presented here should be treated with caution

hadiths.english_translation: Muhammad ibn al-Sa'ib al-Kalbi is called Abu al-Nadhr. His grandfather was Bishr ibn Amr, and his sons were al-Sa'ib, Ubayd, and Abd al-Rahman, who witnessed the Battle of the Camel with Ali ibn Abi Talib (may peace be upon him). Al-Sa'ib ibn Bishr was killed with Mus'ab ibn al-Zubayr. About them, Ibn Warqa al-Nakh'i said: [poetry follows]. Muhammad ibn al-Sa'ib witnessed the Battle of the Skulls with Abd al-Rahman ibn Muhammad ibn al-Ash'ath. Muhammad ibn al-Sa'ib was knowledgeable in Quranic exegesis, Arab genealogies, and their hadith traditions. He died in Kufa in the year 146 AH during the caliphate of Abu Ja'far. Muhammad ibn Sa'd said: His son Hisham ibn Muhammad ibn al-Sa'ib informed me of all this. He was knowledgeable in genealogy and the hadith traditions and history of the Arabs, but the scholars say about him: He is not reliable; in his narration he is very weak.

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd ibn Maniah al-Hajjaji al-Basri

narrators.name: Hisham ibn Muhammad ibn al-Sa'ib

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn al-Sa'ib al-Kalbi

hadiths.english_translation: From Mudhaj, al-Hajjaj is called Abu Artah. He was noble and generous. He was in the company of Abu Ja'far (the Caliph), and he (al-Mahdi) included him (with him), so he remained with him until he died in Rayy (Ray), and al-Mahdi was there at that time during the caliphate of Abu Ja'far. He was weak in hadith.

hadiths.english_translation: One of Banu Marhab, he is called Abu Dhar, and he was a storyteller (qassa). Muhammad ibn Sa'd said: Muhammad ibn Abdullah al-Asadi said: Umar ibn Dhar died in the year 153 AH during the caliphate of Abu Ja'far. He was a Murji'i (one who defers judgment regarding faith and works), then he died, so neither Sufyan al-Thawri nor al-Hasan ibn Salih witnessed it. And he was trustworthy, God willing, prolific in hadith.

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd ibn Maniah al-Hajjaji al-Basri
narrators.transmissionTermMeaning: He said (reporting from Muhammad ibn Abdullah)

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah al-Asadi
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah al-Asadi
narrators.transmissionTermMeaning: He said (reporting about Umar ibn Dhar)

narrators.name: Umar ibn Dhar
narrators.full_name: Umar ibn Dhar ibn Abdullah al-Hamdani

chainIssues: Multiple transmission terms (قَالَ) indicating indirect connections in the biographical chain
The reliability assessment includes a qualifier: 'God willing' (إن شاء الله) suggesting some uncertainty
Reference to Murji'i theological position may indicate sectarian background

potential_issues.impact: The chain uses قَالَ (he said) which indicates indirect transmission through biographical sources rather than direct hadith transmission
The reliability statement includes a qualifier 'God willing' (إن شاء الله), suggesting uncertainty about the assessment

The entry notes that Umar ibn Dhar was a Murji'i (one who defers judgment), which was considered a theological deviance by mainstream Islamic scholars, though it does not necessarily affect hadith reliability

The entry notes that neither Sufyan al-Thawri nor al-Hasan ibn Salih witnessed Umar's death, which may indicate either that he was not well-known to them or that they disagreed with his theological positions
This entry is primarily biographical and historical rather than a hadith transmission with specific religious content

Topics: Biographical Entry of Umar ibn Dhar
